net.fathomsoft.nova.util

Class StringUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.fathomsoft.nova.util.StringUtils

  • public class StringUtils
extends java.lang.Object
    Class that contains methods used for finding data about a String.

      Generate a modified version of the given String in which for every character after the "after" char type that is the same type as the given "removeType" char type will be removed from the String.

      For example: Calling "removeTypeAfterChar("this is an example", 's', ' ')" would return a String "thisisan example"

    • Method Detail

      • findGroupedSymbols

        public static java.lang.String findGroupedSymbols(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                                  int start)
        Get the next sequence of symbols, if they are symbols.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findGroupedSymbols("number = ++num2", 9);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findGroupedSymbols("number = ++num2", 8);
        Scenario 1 returns the "++" String and scenario 2 returns "" because the index that it starts at is whitespace, not a symbol.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search through for the symbols.
        start - The index to start the search at.
        Returns:
        A String containing the grouped chars. If there were no grouped chars, then an empty String is returned.

      • findGroupedSymbols

        public static java.lang.String findGroupedSymbols(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                                  int start,
                                                  int direction)
        Get the next sequence of symbols, if they are symbols.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findGroupedSymbols("number = ++num2", 9, 1);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findGroupedSymbols("number = ++num2", 10, -1);
        Scenario 1 and 2 both return the "++" String because they are searching the same symbols at opposite ends and directions.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search through for the symbols.
        start - The index to start the search at.
        direction - The direction to search for the symbols at.
        Returns:
        A String containing the grouped chars. If there were no grouped chars, then an empty String is returned.

      • findGroupedChars

        public static java.lang.String findGroupedChars(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                                char[] chars,
                                                int start,
                                                int direction)
        Get the next sequence of characters, if they are contained within the given chars array.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findGroupedChars("number = ++num2", StringUtils.SYMBOLS_CHARS, 9, 1);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findGroupedChars("number = ++num2", StringUtils.SYMBOLS_CHARS, 10, -1);
        Scenario 1 and 2 both return the "++" String because they are searching the same symbols at opposite ends and directions.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search through for the characters.
        chars - The chars to search for.
        start - The index to start the search at.
        direction - The direction to search for the characters at.
        Returns:
        A String containing the grouped chars. If there were no grouped chars, then an empty String is returned.

      • findGroupedCharsBounds

        public static Bounds findGroupedCharsBounds(java.lang.String source,
                                            int start,
                                            char[]... types)
        Get the Bounds of the next sequence of characters, if they are contained within the given chars array.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findGroupedCharsBounds("number = ++num2", StringUtils.SYMBOLS_CHARS, 9);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findGroupedCharsBounds("number = ++num2", StringUtils.SYMBOLS_CHARS, 2);
        Scenario 1 returns a Bounds containing [9, 11].
        Scenario 2 returns a Bounds containing [-1, -1], In other words Bounds.EMPTY.
        Parameters:
        source - The String to search through for the characters to find the Bounds from.
        start - The index to start the search at.
        types - Character arrays containing valid characters to search for.
        Returns:
        The Bounds of the location that the characters were found at in the given source String.

      • findGroupedCharsBounds

        public static Bounds findGroupedCharsBounds(java.lang.String source,
                                            int start,
                                            int direction,
                                            boolean opposite,
                                            char[]... types)
        Get the Bounds of the next sequence of characters, if they are contained within the given chars array.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findGroupedCharsBounds("number = ++num2", 9, 1, false, StringUtils.SYMBOLS_CHARS);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findGroupedCharsBounds("number = ++num2", 0, 1, true, StringUtils.SYMBOLS_CHARS);
        Scenario 1 returns a Bounds containing [9, 11].
        Scenario 2 returns a Bounds containing [0, 7].
        Parameters:
        source - The String to search through for the characters to find the Bounds from.
        start - The index to start the search at.
        direction - The direction to search for the characters in.
        opposite - Whether to search for or against the data in the types array.
        types - Character arrays containing valid characters to search for.
        Returns:
        The Bounds of the location that the characters were found at in the given source String.

      • findWordIndex

        public static int findWordIndex(java.lang.String source,
                                java.lang.String word)
        Find the index of the next word in the given source String starting at the start of the source String.
        Parameters:
        source - The source String to search for the next word in.
        word - The word to search for.
        Returns:
        The index of the word. If the word was not found, -1 is returned.

      • findNextWord

        public static java.lang.String findNextWord(java.lang.CharSequence source)
        Find the next word in the given source starting at the beginning of the String. If there are no words available, an empty String is returned.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findNextWord("number = ++num2");
 
 // Scenario 2
 findNextWord("asdf = ++num2");
        Scenario 1 returns "number"
        Scenario 2 returns "asdf"
        Parameters:
        source - The source to search within.
        Returns:
        The next available word if available, else it returns an empty String.

      • findNextWord

        public static java.lang.String findNextWord(java.lang.CharSequence source,
                                            int start)
        Find the next word in the given source starting at the given index. If there are no words available, an empty String is returned.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 0);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 8);
        Scenario 1 returns "number"
        Scenario 2 returns "num2"
        Parameters:
        source - The source to search within.
        start - The index to start the search.
        Returns:
        The next available word if available, else it returns an empty String.

      • findNextWord

        public static java.lang.String findNextWord(java.lang.CharSequence source,
                                            int start,
                                            int direction)
        Find the next word in the given source starting at the given index. If there are no words available, an empty String is returned.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 0, 1);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 8, -1);
        Scenario 1 and 2 both return "number"
        Parameters:
        source - The source to search within.
        start - The index to start the search.
        direction - The direction to search for the word in.
        Returns:
        The next available word if available, else it returns an empty String.

      • findNextLetterIndex

        public static int findNextLetterIndex(java.lang.CharSequence source,
                                      int start,
                                      int direction)
        Find the next index in which a letter resides, starting at the given index. If there are no letters available, -1 is returned.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 0, 1);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 8, -1);
        Scenario 1 returns 0
        Scenario 2 returns 5
        Parameters:
        source - The source to search within.
        start - The index to start the search.
        direction - The direction to search for the word in.
        Returns:
        The next index in which a letter resides. If no letters are found, -1 is returned.

      • findNextLetterIndex

        public static int findNextLetterIndex(java.lang.CharSequence source,
                                      int start,
                                      int direction,
                                      boolean opposite)
        Find the next index in which a letter resides, starting at the given index. If there are no letters available, -1 is returned. However, if the opposite param is true, then the opposite of what was stated above is done.
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 0, 1, true);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 8, -1, true);
        Scenario 1 returns 6
        Scenario 2 returns 8
        Parameters:
        source - The source to search within.
        start - The index to start the search.
        direction - The direction to search for the word in.
        opposite - Whether or not to search for anything that is NOT a letter (instead of searching for a letter).
        Returns:
        The next index in which a letter resides. If no letters are found, -1 is returned.

      • findNextLetterIndex

        public static int findNextLetterIndex(java.lang.CharSequence source,
                                      int start,
                                      int direction,
                                      boolean opposite,
                                      boolean bound)
        Find the next index in which a letter resides, starting at the given index. If there are no letters available, -1 is returned. However, if the opposite param is true, then the opposite of what was stated above is done. Passing true for the bound parameter makes sure that -1 is never returned (It will return the end-point of whichever direction that the method was searching in).
        For example: 
         // Scenario 1
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 11, 1, true);
 
 // Scenario 2
 findNextWord("number = ++num2", 4, -1, true, true);
        Scenario 1 returns 15
        Scenario 2 returns 0
        Parameters:
        source - The source to search within.
        start - The index to start the search.
        direction - The direction to search for the word in.
        opposite - Whether or not to search for anything that is NOT a letter (instead of searching for a letter).
        bound - Whether or not to bound the result returned if the a result was not found.
        Returns:
        The next index in which a letter resides.

      • findEndingMatch

        public static int findEndingMatch(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                  int index,
                                  char startChar,
                                  char endChar)
        Find the index of the ending char for the match. For instance, to search for an ending parenthesis, starting from the opening parenthesis, you would pass findEndingMatch(str, 0, '(', ')'); The method call would return the index of the ending parenthesis that is paired with the index of 0.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search for the pair to the start char.
        index - The index of the start char in the pair.
        startChar - The char that starts off the pair. eg. '('
        endChar - The char that ends the pair. eg: ')'
        Returns:
        The index of the pair to the starting char, if no pair is found then -1 is returned.

      • findEndingMatch

        public static int findEndingMatch(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                  int index,
                                  char startChar,
                                  char endChar,
                                  int direction)
        Find the index of the ending char for the match. For instance, to search for an ending parenthesis, starting from the opening parenthesis, you would pass findEndingMatch(str, 0, '(', ')'); The method call would return the index of the ending parenthesis that is paired with the index of 0.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search for the pair to the start char.
        index - The index of the start char in the pair.
        startChar - The char that starts off the pair. eg. '('
        endChar - The char that ends the pair. eg: ')'
        direction - The direction in which to search for the match in.
        Returns:
        The index of the pair to the starting char, if no pair is found then -1 is returned.

      • findEndingMatch

        public static int findEndingMatch(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                  int index,
                                  char startChar,
                                  char endChar,
                                  char escapeChar)
        Find the index of the ending char for the match. For instance, to search for an ending parenthesis, starting from the opening parenthesis, you would pass findEndingMatch(str, 0, '(', ')', '\\'); (The backslash would act to escape any parentheses. eg: \\( would not be counted.) The method call would return the index of the ending parenthesis that is paired with the index of 0.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search for the pair to the start char.
        index - The index of the start char in the pair.
        startChar - The char that starts off the pair. eg. '('
        endChar - The char that ends the pair. eg: ')'
        escapeChar - The char that escapes a start or end char, of there is no escape char, pass '(char)0'.
        Returns:
        The index of the pair to the starting char, if no pair is found then -1 is returned.

      • findEndingMatch

        public static int findEndingMatch(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                  int index,
                                  char startChar,
                                  char endChar,
                                  char escapeChar,
                                  int direction)
        Find the index of the ending char for the match. For instance, to search for an ending parenthesis, starting from the opening parenthesis, you would pass findEndingMatch(str, 0, '(', ')', '\\'); (The backslash would act to escape any parentheses. eg: \\( would not be counted.) The method call would return the index of the ending parenthesis that is paired with the index of 0.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search for the pair to the start char.
        index - The index of the start char in the pair.
        startChar - The char that starts off the pair. eg. '('
        endChar - The char that ends the pair. eg: ')'
        escapeChar - The char that escapes a start or end char, of there is no escape char, pass '(char)0'.
        direction - The direction in which to search for the match in.
        Returns:
        The index of the pair to the starting char, if no pair is found then -1 is returned.

      • findEndingQuote

        public static int findEndingQuote(java.lang.CharSequence value,
                                  int start)
        Find the index of the ending quote, given the index of the start quote.
        Parameters:
        value - The String to search within.
        start - The index of the starting quote.
        Returns:
        The index of the ending quote. If an end is not found, -1 is returned instead.

      • findEndingQuote

        public static int findEndingQuote(java.lang.CharSequence value,
                                  int start,
                                  int direction)
        Find the index of the ending quote, given the index of the start quote.
        Parameters:
        value - The String to search within.
        start - The index of the starting quote.
        direction - The direction in which to search the given String.
        Returns:
        The index of the ending quote. If an end is not found, -1 is returned instead.

      • findEndingChar

        public static int findEndingChar(java.lang.CharSequence value,
                                 char c,
                                 int start,
                                 int direction)
        Find the index of the ending char that matches the given 'c' param, given the index of the start char.
        Parameters:
        value - The String to search within.
        c - The char to search for an end for.
        start - The index of the starting quote.
        direction - The direction in which to search the given String.
        Returns:
        The index of the matching char. If an end is not found, -1 is returned instead.

      • findStrings

        public static Bounds findStrings(java.lang.CharSequence value,
                                 java.lang.String[] strings)
        Search through the given value for any match within the strings array.
        Parameters:
        value - The String to search through.
        strings - The array to search through.
        Returns:
        A Bounds instance with the end points of the found String. If a String is not found, [-1, -1] is returned.

      • findStrings

        public static Bounds findStrings(java.lang.CharSequence value,
                                 java.lang.String[] strings,
                                 int start)
        Search through the given value for any match within the strings array.
        Parameters:
        value - The String to search through.
        strings - The array to search through.
        start - The index to start the search at.
        Returns:
        A Bounds instance with the end points of the found String. If a String is not found, [-1, -1] is returned.

      • findStrings

        public static Bounds findStrings(java.lang.CharSequence value,
                                 java.lang.String[] strings,
                                 int start,
                                 int direction)
        Search through the given value for any match within the strings array.
        Parameters:
        value - The String to search through.
        strings - The array to search through.
        start - The index to start the search at.
        direction - The direction to search in.
        Returns:
        A Bounds instance with the end points of the found String. If a String is not found, [-1, -1] is returned.

      • findMatch

        public static java.lang.String findMatch(java.lang.String haystack,
                                         java.lang.String[] strings,
                                         int start)
        Search the given haystack String for any match within the strings array starting at the given char start index. If a match is encountered, the String that makes the match is returned. If not match is made, null is returned.
        Parameters:
        haystack - The String try to match.
        strings - The array to search through to try and match.
        start - The index to start to search the value at.
        Returns:
        The String in the strings array that made the match. If no match was found, null is returned.

      • getMatch

        public static java.lang.String getMatch(java.lang.String haystack,
                                        java.lang.String[] strings,
                                        int index)
        Search the given haystack String for any match within the strings array at the given char offset index. If a match is encountered, the String that makes the match is returned. If not match is made, null is returned.
        Parameters:
        haystack - The String try to match at the given index.
        strings - The array to search through to try and match.
        index - The index to search the value at.
        Returns:
        The String in the strings array that made the match. If no match was found, null is returned.

      • matches

        public static boolean matches(java.lang.String haystack,
                              java.lang.String[] strings,
                              int index)
        Search the given haystack String for any match within the strings array at the given char offset index.
        Parameters:
        haystack - The String try to match at the given index.
        strings - The array to search through to try and match.
        index - The index to search the value at.
        Returns:
        Whether or not there is a match within the strings array at the given index in the haystack String.

        start - The index to start the search at.
        statementStart - The index to end the search at.
        source - The source String to search in.
        Returns:
        The number of lines that the iterator encountered within the given bounds.

      • findNextCharacter

        public static int findNextCharacter(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                    char[] chars,
                                    int index,
                                    int direction)
        Get the next possible index in the String that contains a char in the given character array, while moving in the specified direction. If none exists, -1 is returned.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search through.
        chars - The array of valid characters to search for.
        index - The index to start the search at.
        direction - The direction in which to increment the index.
        Returns:
        The next possible index in the String that is a character in the given array.

      • findNextCharacter

        public static int findNextCharacter(java.lang.CharSequence str,
                                    char[] chars,
                                    int index,
                                    int direction,
                                    boolean opposite)
        Get the next possible index in the String that contains a char in the given character array, while moving in the specified direction. If none exists, -1 is returned.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to search through.
        chars - The array of valid characters to search for.
        index - The index to start the search at.
        direction - The direction in which to increment the index.
        opposite - Whether or not to search for or against what is within the character array.
        Returns:
        The next possible index in the String that is a character in the given array.

      • escapeSpaces

        public static java.lang.String escapeSpaces(java.lang.String input)
        Escape the spaces in an input String.

        For example: An input of "this is a test" would return "this\ is\ a\ test"
        Parameters:
        input - The String to escape the spaces from.
        Returns:
        The input String with escaped spaces.

      • splitCommas

        public static java.lang.String[] splitCommas(java.lang.String src)
        Split the src by the commas. Makes sure not to split commas that are within parentheses and quotes.
        Parameters:
        src - The String to split the commas from.
        Returns:
        An array of Strings containing the Strings that were split.

      • trimToIdentifier

        public static java.lang.String trimToIdentifier(java.lang.String statement)
        Trim the given statement to strictly an identifier.

        For example: A call of "trimToIdentifier("**identifer322&+")" would return "identifier322"
        Parameters:
        statement - The statement to trim down.
        Returns:
        The trimmed down identifier.

      • findLastMissingString

        public static java.lang.String findLastMissingString(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> words,
                                                     java.lang.String statement)
        Find the String value of the data that is in between the last two words in the array.

        For example: A call of findLastMissingString([this, is, a, test], "this.is->a==test") would return "=="
        Parameters:
        words - The list of words that lead of up the desired value.
        statement - The String to search the words with.
        Returns:
        The data that was found.

      • reverseIndexOf

        public static int reverseIndexOf(java.lang.String haystack,
                                 java.lang.String needle,
                                 int start)
        Search backwards for the index of the next available match of the needle within the haystack String, if a match exists. The search starts at the given index.
        Parameters:
        haystack - The String to search through.
        needle - The String to search for.
        start - The index to start the reverse search for.
        Returns:
        The next available index.

      • reverseMatches

        public static boolean reverseMatches(java.lang.String haystack,
                                     java.lang.String needle,
                                     int index)
        Get whether or not the needle matches the haystack at the given index.

        For example: A call of reverseMatches("this will work", "will", 8) would return true.
        Parameters:
        haystack - The String to search for the needle in.
        needle - The String to search in the haystack for.
        index - The index to search for the match at.
        Returns:
        Whether or not there is a match at the given index.

      • removeTypeAfterChar

        public static java.lang.String removeTypeAfterChar(java.lang.String str,
                                                   char after,
                                                   char removeType)
        Generate a modified version of the given String in which for every character after the "after" char type that is the same type as the given "removeType" char type will be removed from the String.

        For example: Calling "removeTypeAfterChar("this is an example", 's', ' ')" would return a String "thisisan example"
        Parameters:
        str - The String to generate a modified version of.
        after - The char type to search for the remove type directly after.
        removeType - The type of char to remove.
        Returns:
        The newly formatted String.
